intro: Dipidax ciliata f. caerulea, commonly known as the blue-fringed bellflower, is a flowering plant belonging to the Campanulaceae family. It is characterized by its striking blue or purple bell-shaped flowers that hang in clusters, adding a vibrant touch to gardens. The plant features slender, hairy stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves with prominent cilia along the edges. Native to southern Europe, it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade. This cultivar is valued for its ornamental appeal and ease of cultivation in temperate climates.
